div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7219] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, JUNE 20, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
JAPANESE ADVANCE. RUSSIANS FALLING BACK. LINIEVITCH’S REPORT.
div.p: London, June 19. The ‘'Daily Telegraph” learns from Tokio that the Russians are bringing up reserves to reinforce their forward lines, which are only 70 miles distant from General Kuroki’s outposts. (Reuter.)
Tokio, June 19 The advance of the Japanese in Manchuria is general. The Russians are retiring. (Havas.)

St. Petersburg, June 19. General Linievitch reports that the Japanese force which occupied Liaoyang-Woping consisted of a division of infantry, 30 squadrons of cavalry, and 4 batteries of artillery. The attack began at 2 and ended at 8 a.m., when the Russians were outflanked. He makes no reference to losses, but adds that reports from Korea show that the Japanese have advanced from Kongchan to Munsan. (Reuter)

div.head: DISEASE RAMPANT AT KHARBIN.
div.p: London, June 19. It is reported that cholera and dysentery are still raging at Kharbin, where the death rate is 100 per diem. There are now 56,000 sick and wounded in the hospitals there. (R.)

div.head: ZEMSTVOS DEPUTIES. RECEIVED BY THE TSAR. NATIONAL ASSEMBLY TO BE CONVOKED.
div.p: St. Petersburg, June 19. The Tsar received the members of the Zemstvos to-day. There are no details.
(Later). The Tsar informed the deputation of Zemstvos that he is unalterably resolved to convoke a National Assembly.

The deputation was fully official and included three deputies from St Petersburg, Prince Troubetzkois addressed the Tsar for half-an-hour dwelling on the melancholy state of Russia. The Tsar, deeply moved, said that he regrets the enormous sacrifices caused by the war, particularly the defeat of Toushima, and that the convocation of a National Assembly will be his daily care. He hopes that the Zemstvos will from, to-day assist in the work which will re unite Russia to the Tsar-dom. The delegates were pleased with the reception they received. (Reuter.)

St. Petersburg, June 19. The Tsar has received the deputation of the Zemstvos Congress. Prince Troubetzkoi explained the situation to him. The Tsar expressed bis regret for the enormous sacrifices caused by the war and added that his unshaken wish was to summon a National Assembly. (H.)

div.head: WARSAW JEWS DISTURBED. INDIGNATION MEETINGS.
div.p: Warsaw, June 19. The Jews here are extremely disturbed on account of the report that the scheme for popular representation excludes them from the right of franchise. Numerous indignation meetings have been held, which have been dispersed bv the police and troops. (Reuter.)

div.head: The Plague
div.p: Yesterday’s bulletin records four oases (two fatal) and a death in hospital at Damanhour, one case at Toukh, and another at Ashmoun.

div.head: Drowinng Accident
div.p: The body of the carpenter of the S.S. “Clio,” who fell overboard in Alexandria harbour a few days ago, was recovered yesterday and sent to hospital for the usual coroner’s inquest.

div.head: Alexandria Police
div.p: Local Kaimakams G. Cobbe Bey and M. Moberly Bey, Assistant Commandant of Police in Alexandria and Cairo, respectively, have been granted the commission of Kaimakam.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 12 vessels passed through the Canal on the 16th inst., 8 of which were British, 2 German, 1 Dutch, 1 Turkish. The day’s receipts were frs. 316,290:63, making the total from 1st inst. frs. 4,457,664.75.

div.head: The Unknown Forces
div.p: We may remind our readers of the fact that on Thursday next, Prof, de Lafontaine, the hypnotist, will give his first seance at the Eden Theatre, assisted by his Creole mediums from Mauritius.

div.head: Killed by a Fish
div.p: A fisherman, while fishing near Shebin el Com, caught a fish and held it in his teeth. The man, being engaged in collecting his fish from the net, relaxed his jaws and the fish darted down his throat, suffocating him almost immediately.

div.head: Execution of a Parricide
div.p: Mahmoud Ibrahim Eid El Gazar, of Ballabish, Baliana district, suffered the last penalty of the law this morning at the prison of the Native Court of Appeal, Cairo. It will be remembered that the man was found guilty of the murder of his father near Deyrout in September, 1904.

div.head: Measles in Upper Egypt
div.p: An outbreak of measles is reported from villages in the Esna district. Orders have been issued by the Ministry of the Interior that all cases are to be notified under penalty of fine and that owners of esheshes or huts where cases occur are to limewash their dwellings and provide them with such openings as the district inspector may deem necessary.

div.head: Attempted Murder
div.p: At 9 p.m. yesterday an Armenian local subject in company with a Greek attacked a Greek barber in the Eastern Telegraph-street, striking him across the face with a stick and attempting to stab him. The barber made a successful resistance and overpowered his would-be murderer, who was arrested, together with his confederate. It appears that the Armenian had previously threatened to murder the barber.

div.head: THE MAHMAL THEFT. ANDRAOUS’S ANTECEDENTS.
div.p: Let us hope that Andraous Meloka has no rivals in his art. A thief, who can board a moving train and drop off with his booty unobserved and uninjured, is a redoubtable opponent of society in general and the Railway Administration in particular. We are now assured that Andraous was never employed by the railway authorities. He certainly appears to have given them a good deal of employment, for was not he condemned to six years imprisonment in 1895 for a series of daring and ingenious train robberies ? Now we are assured that he was employed by the police, no doubt on the principle of set a thief to catch a thief but the report is unfounded. Andraous’ time has been too much taken up of late years. Condemned for burglary in 1888 by the Native Court of Appeal, he took to train robbery on his release from prison until 1895. After being employed for some years in the buildings of the Prisons Department he returned to the world and stole jewels at Shoubra. Six months and life at Assiout under the observation of the authorities were the result, and now, Andraous has performed his boldest and his last exploit.

He denied any participation in the crime before the Parquet, but that was only to be expected. His confederates also denied it, which was rather remarkable, for the honor that is said to exist among thieves seldom prevents at least one member of a gang from giving the authorities full information of his comrades misdeeds when he has been laid by the beels.

"Cherchez la femme” was the motto of the Parquet, and on Sunday Andraous’ wife appeared for examination. Her statement was clear, enough. Four months ago her husband came home with Makarius and Ibrahim Ashour, told his wife not to disturb them, and shut himself up with his friends. With the curiosity of her sex the Sitt Meloka listened and heard the clinking of coin. The trio were obviously dividing the "swag.”

Andraous had made a capital error in not sending his wife out of the house or looking her in her room. He was soon to make another. After seeing his friends off the premises he presented his spouse with a handkerchief full of sovereigns and bade her guard them. A few days later he made a hole in the wall and there hid a tin box containing the coins; sis wife wondered where they came from, and Andraous weakly told the story and sealed his fate.

Mansfield Pasha and Goubran Bay Moskat have supplied Mr. Machell with the results of the inquiry up to date. The decision of the Ministry of War, with regard to the members of the military escort which was of such little use in guarding the treasure, may be deferred till the enquiry has brought to light all the circumstances of the robbery.

div.head: RAMLEH BOULEVARD BURGLARY.
div.p: It is evident from the way in which the safe at Mr. Caffari’s office has been prised open that it was a job which occupied five hours.

A gentleman, who passed by at about 1 p.m., states that he saw a light in the office through the Windows. The ghaffir invariably knocks at the door, when owing to press of work the office has been occupied and lighted up to 10 p.m. It is curious that on the night in question he did not notice anything, and his conduct is suspicions.
The wholesale value of the silver stolen from the plate stores is L.E. 54.
Two men, a Greek and a native, have been arrested on suspicion of being the thieves.

div.head: RED SEA WRECKS. BRITISH CRUISER RENDERING AID
div.p: From our Correspondent). Suez, Mondav. The Anchor Line steamer "Massilia,” which arrived at Suez this morning from Bombay, reported that the British steamer "Foyle,” from Rangoon, was badly ashore in the Red Sea south of Hanish island, near Gebel Zuhur. As I stated in my telegram this morning, I understand that this steamer has a full cargo of rice for Alexandria.

The "Foyle” is apparently in a very bad position, and several native dhows were sighted in the vicinity ; they are supposed to be pirates. A British cruiser was proceeding at the time towards the wreck to render assistance.

The other rice steamer "Helen Rickmers,” is still fast near Ras Garib, viz., 14 miles south of the lighthouse, and has a heavy list The Khedivial Mail liner "Rahmanieh,” which left Suez last Saturday night with lighters and labourers, is now rendering assistance and receiving cargo discharged from the wreck. The weather is continuing good, and salvage operations are progressing favorably.

div.head: BROTHERS ISLAND LIGHTHOUSE. TO BE PULLED DOWN.
div.p: The present lighthouse on the Brothers Island (in the Red Sea) is about to be palled down, and a larger one erected in its place, with a more powerful light.

The work will be commenced on, or shortly after, October 1 next, when the present light will be discontinued, and in its place two lamps, each showing a fixed white light, will be placed one at either end of the island.
These lights will each be about 1,000 candle power and hung on poles about 30 feet high.
The new light will be white, flashing.

div.head: THEWFIKIEH NILE COMPANY.
div.p: The affairs of the above company seem again to be causing quite a ferment in some native circles in Cairo in consequence of the non-fulfilment of their duties by the two liquidators appointed last October as well as the action taken lately by some former shareholders in instituting proceedings before the Mixed Tribunals for the recovery of the money paid for shares, on the ground that the shares were sold through wilful misrepresentation on the part of the former board of directors. Besides the shareholders there are innumerable creditor clamouring for settlement of their accounts who for some time after the company stopped payment were kept quiet with the promise that the late Menshawi Pasha would liquidate all outstanding debts and take over the whole concern to work himself. These promises not being fulfilled, and the liquidators having neglected to carry out their mandate, matters have again assumed an acute stage.

The civil action of' the shareholders was before the Courts last Saturday and has been set down for hearing after the vacation. At the same time criminal proceedings, as we have already announced, will be begun against the members of the former board, when some very sensational disclosures regarding the financing of the late Thewfikieh Nile Navigation Company are expected to be made public.

div.head: SUPPLY FROM ARTESIAN WELLS.
div.p: The Cairo Water Company is now supplying water to the principal districts from seven artesian wells, fire of which are worked from engines at Rod-el-Farag and two from the Bonlae engines. The districts so supplied are Shoubra, Boulac, Fagallah, Esbekieh, Ismailia, and Kasr-el-Aiui, whilst the Abbassieh, Gamalieh, Darb-el-Abmar, Khalifa, and Saida Zenab districts still receive their water supply through the Abbassieh filters.

Dr. Bitter is occupied in making an analysis of the water which comes from the artesian wells, so that at present we cannot give any information as to the quality of the water and its purity, but we will publish the results of Dr. Bitter’s investigation as soon as they are completed. As regards the quantity of the water, 65,000 cubic metres are being daily pumped through the Cairo mains, of which 25,000 cubic metres come from the seven artesian wells in use and 40,000 cubic metres pass through the Abbassieh filters. Two more wells at Rod-el-Farag are being prepared, and it is anticipated that these will be completed in four months’ time; and should the system prove to be thoroughly satisfactory after two years’ trial the number of wells will be increased to sixteen.

The supply of water to Zeitoun cpmes from a special well in that locality, but unfortunately it has proved very deficient as regards quantity, and the Water Company has no hopes of improving the conditions for another two months, by which time they will have another engine working and so double the present supply. In laying the plant for the Zeitoun supply the company estimated that it would not be necessary to exceed the amount supplied to Assiout (2,500 cubio metres per day) and they accordingly constructed an engine capable of pumping 3,000 cubic metres per day, and Zeitoun is now receiving that quantify, the engine being kept working throughout the 24 hours. Meanwhile the remedy lies in the hands of the residents, and if they refrain from using the large quantities which are at present being used for watering the gardens, they will find that the supply is ample for domestic purposes. It must be remembered that the sandy soil of Zeitonn will absorb almost any quantity of water and it is evident that the amount so wasted is considerable.

div.head: CAIRO WATER SUPPLY. KHEDIVIAL LAW SCHOOL.
div.p: The following advertisement has been despatched to the London newspapers :— The Egyptian Ministry of Public Instruction invites applications for two posts of lecturers In the English section of the above-mentioned School. Salary £615, rising to £830. Candidates must be University Men, having either a Law Degree or other legal qualification, and must have a moderate know ledge of French. They will be required in the first instance to Lecture (in English) on Jurisprudence, Roman Law, or Political Economy.—applications, stating ago and qualifications, accompanied by copies only of Testimonials, should be made by letter to M. Sheldon An os, Esq. If posted In London not later than June 17, 1901, they should be addressed to the Native Court of First Instance, Cairo. Later applications should be addressed to St. Ermin’s Hotel, Westminster.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: T. H. the Princess Said Halim and Hussein Kamel, with many notables, have called upon the Grand Mufti at his residence in Ramleh.
Lord Dormer, who arrived in Egypt on the 31st May in connection with a new land company that is being formed, is returning to England to-day, by way of Marseilles, by the P.O. steamer "Persia.”

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
RAISING THE CONGAL.
div.p: The caisson round the sunken S.S. "Congal” was completed by Sunday morning. It is composed of 2-inch deal and pine planks and is shored from side to side and to the deck with balks of heavy timber jointed at the bleak edges and well caulked. At 10 a.m. yesterday the pumping was started, divers being in attendance. Several times, however, work had to be stopped to allow of alterations being made. All night pumping continued, and this morning a large centrifugal pump was got to work under the ship to wash away the mud which had formed along her side. At about 11 a.m. the vessel suddenly lifted aft about a foot and steadily from then on she lifted. She now is (8 p.m.) well up aft, but the bow still remains touching the bottom. The dry-dock is ready to receive her the moment her draft of water will allow, and it is expected that by evening she will be ready to be put in the dock. The cost of raising the vessel will amount to £1,400.

MORE RUSSIAN REFUGEES I learn from an official source that 33,000 more Russian refugees am to return from Port Arthuron parole. Four Hamburg-American vessels are chartered already. One of them, the "Trave,” is now in Port Said and leaves for the East today.

div.head: CAPTURE OF HASHISH.
div.p: Three or four days ago, a large haul of hashish was made by the coastguards here. The smugglers were traced by their footprints in the sand some considerable distance from the canal bank a little north of Ismailia and the hashish, from 650 to 700 kilos, was discovered by the coastguards bidden in a field. The smugglers have not been caught so far.
